Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Assessments of the Impacts of Decentralized Land Use and Water Management Practices in Urban Ecosystems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1150994(Montalto) This project will advance knowledge about poorly understood hydrologic processes that occur on vegetated and impervious land parcels in dense urban environments, and their relationship to ecosystem services. Special attention is paid to the watershed-scale implications of deliberate micro-scale redirections of water in ultra-urban settings, e.g. green infrastructure (GI) projects. The research makes use of existing sensors in GI monitoring sites that the PI has assembled with other resources, but which are not currently integrated into a network. A new relational database will link this collection of sites and sensors and support complex and highly specific data retrieval queries, with significantly more sites and sensors to be made available by project collaborators. The results of these queries will advance knowledge about the hydrologic outcomes that can be expected from different GI treatments implemented in different contexts. The database will enable efficient longitudinal (e.g. between sites), and/or vertical (e.g. between sensors) discoveries regarding the hydrologic performance of GI. Without this database, such queries would be nearly impossible to perform efficiently. Because the GI systems included in the database receive runoff from different sized source areas, the database will also facilitate potentially transformative investigations into the effects of scale on urban hydrology. Agent models will provide simulation platforms within which to explore the relative importance of different hydrologic, climatological, and social uncertainties in predicting emergent watershed-scale ecosystem services, in different urban neighborhoods. With "hydrologic response rules" derived directly from data stored in the relational database, the models will enhance ability to accurately depict urban scale hydrologic fluxes under different innovative management regimes. Community members will be actively involved in the agent-model building process. The research will yield findings relevant to technical practitioners (engineers, urban designers, water utility representatives), natural scientists (ecologists, hydrologists, biologists,) as well as to planners (community groups, municipal sustainability directors), and a range of interdisciplinary academic researchers. The research is structured to provide opportunities for the participation of a diverse set of undergraduate and graduate students, community members, and government and non-profit partners. The Citizen Science program, recruiting at least 50% from demographic groups traditionally underrepresented in science, will engage residents of five study neighborhoods in data collection activities, and is intended to become a model for two-way learning between university researchers and the urban community. A Sustainable Water Resource Engineering (SWRE) Field Training (FT) Program will provide a forum for encouraging the participation of undergraduate students in research. The FT projects will be used to create a database of innovative water projects and SWRE teaching modules which will be available to the public on the PI?s institutional website. New urban ecohydrologic data sets will be streamed in real-time to a Drexel server that will be linked to the CUAHSI Hydrologic Information Service through web-services. This new infrastructure will make the data assembled and organized as part of this project accessible to the larger hydrologic research community. Semi-annual meetings with a Scientific Advisory Committee will ensure dissemination of the research findings. Collaborations have also been forged with a) the USEPA-NRML offices in Edison, NJ, taking advantage of a recently signed MOU between EPA and NSF, and b) the Baltimore Ecosystem Study, one of one of two urban nodes in NSF?s Long-Term Ecological Research network. Through the project, the PI will also continue collaborating with researchers from Columbia University, with whom he is already working as part of the NOAA-funded Consortium on Climate Risks in the Urban Northeast.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

Through a wide range of monitoring and modeling activities, this integrated research and education plan investigated the extent to which specific decentralized water management and land use practices (aka green infrastructure- GI) can be used to enhance, restore, or create ecosystem services in urban watersheds. The study sites included green roofs, permeable pavements, rain gardens, bioswales, constructed wetlands, rainwater cisterns, tree pits and other similar facilities in urban watersheds of New York City,  Philadelphia, and Camden.

The interdisciplinary research activities were performed by one full-time research assistant, as well as a host of other graduate and undergraduate students engaged through the PI's Sustainable Water Resource Engineering (SWRE) Field Training Program (FTP), one of the core elements of the project's educational plan. In the tradition of problem-based contextualized learning, this program awarded undergraduate and graduate students engineering elective credits for independent research performed under the supervision of the PI. The independent study projects were structured so as to promote discovery and learning in the fields of urban ecohydrology, urban climate, hydrologic and hydraulic modeling, as well as agent-based modeling, and participatory methods, but they also helped the PI to test the project hypotheses. Field data gathered through the project was also regularly incorporated into the PI's classroom activities and projects.

Another core component of the project was a Citizen Scientist Internship (CSI) Program  administered through GrowNYC, and designed by Public Workshop. Targeting a different group of individuals, this innovative program facilitated independent learning and discovery, by employing residents of the study neighborhoods to assist in the research. Participants included community gardeners, science teachers, and students, with preference given to individuals from groups traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering. The CSIs served a central role in field data collection and validation, due to their residence in, and familiarity with, the various study neighborhoods.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

The research revealed the ecohydrologic and ecosystem service implications of deliberate (re)direction of urban stormwater to a wide range of GI sites, positioned in different urban micrometeorological contexts. For example, the team documented the ability of green roofs to attenuate incident precipitation, and incoming solar radiation, compared the in-situ surface infiltration rates of tree pits, green streets, permeable pavements, permeable playground surfaces, and urban parks that have been designed and maintained in specific ways, and  compared the stormwater capture performance of rain gardens, lined and unlined constructed wetlands, and urban yard spaces under both extreme and non-extreme precipitation conditions. We established that when runon is directed to vegetated green spaces, evapotranspiration rates are accelerated (compared to sites that receive only direct rainfall). Those sites also maintain higher mean soil moisture levels, especially during the summer, with likely implications on urban soil biogeochemistry and related processes. Differences in soil moisture availability were also shown to yield differences in leaf transpiration, and above- and below-ground biomass accumulation, though species-specific differences in tolerance to both heat stress and waterlogging were also observed.

For GI practices to increase ecosystem services such as urban heat island mitigation, combined sewer overflow reduction, climate and water regulation in meaningful ways, GI systems needs to be strategically and significantly incorporated into urban landscapes. Using deliberative policy analysis, semi-structured interviews, structured surveys, and other stakeholder engagement methodologies, the research team uncovered many of the institutional, socioeconomic, and policy-related opportunities and constraints to GI upscaling in a range of urban contexts. A variety of multi-domain modeling platforms (e.g. mediated modeling tools, agent-based models) were then used to  identify GI siting and design strategies that can maximize the ecosystem service benefits of GI systems funded principally as municipal wet weather programs.

Along the way, we’ve made important methodological contributions, for example regarding the suitability of classical equations for simulating urban evapotranspiration, soil heat flux, and runoff, but also regarding the scale, resolution, and unit processes that need to be included in hydrologic and hydraulic models to be able to simulate GI's potential watershed-scale impacts. 

Broader Impacts Outcomes:

The broad goal of these cross-disciplinary studies was to identify cost-effective GI strategies that respond to the needs of diverse local stakeholders, transforming GI investments into a key catalyst for urban sustainability and resilience in regenerated cities. This research has a very wide potential audience as municipal GI programs exceeding $1 billion in investment are now many across the country. By conducting the research in lock step with practitioners, citizen scientists, and students (from the field to the classroom) the opportunity for knowledge transfer and application was maximized. The data collected as part of this CAREER program is vast and will remain a resource for future students and practitioners at Drexel and beyond.
